ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to analyze extensive secondary articles and how to interpret primary sources. Additionally, I learned how to synthesize sources to establish an argument and have supporting evidence.

I learned how to critically read primary and secondary sources from the perspective of a historian of childhood/domesticity. This culminated in a final project where I learned how to write my own research paper. 

Most of this course was focused on Korea, Japan, and China, and we read sources mostly focusing on 1800s and 1900s, which we covered extensively from topics ranging from the idea of the "modern girl" to medical missionaries and imperialism focusing on childcare.
A good survey of the way childhood and domesticity evolved in East Asia.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The classroom dynamic was very welcoming, and the articles were very interesting to read. On the other hand, I felt like some of them were very difficult to read, and there were way too many readings for some of the weeks.

This course was very very well structured. While I really did like the first few readings we did for the "Introduction" and "Childhood as Methodology" weeks, I think it would've been more effective to read some of these broad readings about the study of the history of childhood in the last few weeks of class, after we had spent a lot of time critically reading history in that way.

Strengths: the peer led discussions and seminars and readings
Weaknesses: not many

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yessss I would recommend it to another student, especially if they want to learn more about this niche subject. I took the class to learn more about East Asian cultures, and even though the topic was very specific, it also touched upon general history that one should know about.

Yes I would definitely recommend it because it gave me a different perspective of viewing history, and I learned a lot. However, I would advise them that it is a lot of work. There was a lot of reading for the class every week and it was dense. Also, because our midterm and final paper were research papers, we spent a lot of time researching our topic of choice to reach the final paper.
YES I WOULD THE CLASS, THE READINGS, AND PRO HEO WERE SO AMAZING so even if pro heo won't be teaching this class anymore, I think this class should still be offered!!!!
